Package com.drbhagwat.Chapter1

  • Class Summary 
    Class Description
    Exercise1
    The following program is a solution to Exercise1 in Chapter1.
    Exercise10
    Write a program that produces a random string of letters and digits by generating a random long value and printing it in base 36.
    Exercise11
    Write a program that that reads a line of text and prints all the characters that are not ASCII together with their Unicode values.
    Exercise13
    Write a program that prints a lottery combination, picking six distinct numbers between 1 and 49.
    Exercise14
    Write Write a program that reads a two dimensional array of integers and determines whether it is a magic square (that is, whether the sum of all rows, all columns, and the diagonals is the same).
    Exercise15  
    Exercise16  
    Exercise3
    This program reads three integers and prints the largest.
    Exercise4
    This program prints the smallest and largest positive double values: Hint: Lookup Math.nextUp in the Java API.
    Exercise5
    This program prints when you cast a double (that is larger than the largest possible int) to an int.
    Exercise6
    This program computes 1000! using BigInteger.
    Exercise7
    This program reads in two integers between 0 and 4294967295, stores them in int variables, and computes and displays their unsigned sum, difference, product, quotient, and remainder.
    Exercise8
    This program reads a string and prints all of its substrings.
    Exercise9
    Section 1.5.3, "String comparison" (Page 25) has an example of two strings s and t so that s.equals(t) but s != t.
